questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulty rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two late-night serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L, respectively (N < 90); 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement is 395 μg (N < 300). Additional studies show a serum ACTH level of 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inferior petrosal sinus sampling may be performed as part of the diagnostic workup of certain patients with secondary hypercortisolism. However, another diagnostic test is more appropriate at this point.

B) CORRECT:

Secondary hypercortisolism is most commonly caused by an ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) and less commonly by ectopic ACTH production. In patients with suspected secondary hypercortisolism, hormone testing (e.g., high-dose dexamethasone suppression test, CRH stimulation test) was previously the first-line test but current guidelines recommend a pituitary MRI to assess for Cushing disease as the most appropriate next step in evaluation. A pituitary adenoma of > 10 mm confirms the diagnosis of Cushing disease. If the MRI does not show a pituitary adenoma or the findings are unclear, inferior petrosal sinus sampling (to measure ACTH levels) or hormone testing should be performed.

C) INCORRECT:

The low-dose dexamethasone suppression test (LDDST) is one of four tests that may be used to diagnose Cushing syndrome (along with a late-night salivary cortisol test, late-night serum cortisol test, and 24-hour urinary cortisol). Hypercortisolism is confirmed if at least two of the tests have abnormal results. As this patient already has the required two abnormal results needed to establish the diagnosis (elevated late-night serum cortisol and 24-hour urinary cortisol), the LDDST is not required.

D) INCORRECT:

An abdominal CT scan is obtained in patients with primary hypercortisolism to locate adrenal masses or hyperplasia. Patients with primary hypercortisolism would have low ACTH levels. A pathology located within the abdomen (e.g., renal cell carcinoma) is a less common cause of secondary hypercortisolism. For patients with secondary hypercortisolism, abdominal imaging is only considered if other steps in the workup are inconclusive.

E) INCORRECT:

The corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) stimulation test may be used to differentiate between pituitary and ectopic ACTH production in Cushing syndrome. A further increase in serum ACTH and cortisol levels after CRH stimulation indicates Cushing disease; minimal or no change suggests ectopic ACTH production. However, another diagnostic test is required first.
questions.hint: Weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, menstrual cycle changes, depression, truncal obesity, striae, and hypertension are suggestive of hypercortisolism (Cushing syndrome). Elevated serum ACTH indicates secondary hypercortisolism.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and irregular menstrual cycles for the past year. She also complains of recurrent sinus infections. During the past 6 months, she has had increased urinary frequency and swelling of her feet. She has also had difficulty lifting her 3-year-old niece for the past 3 weeks. She was recently diagnosed with depression. She works as a medical assistant. The patient has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks four beers on the weekends. Her only medication is escitalopram. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (175 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows excess fat around the base of the neck and an enlarged abdomen. Examination of the skin shows multiple bruises on her arms and legs. There is generalized weakness and atrophy of the proximal muscles. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Na+

150 mEq/L


K+

3.0 mEq/L


Cl-

103 mEq/L


HCO3-

30 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
19 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Glucose
136 mg/dL


A 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test shows a serum cortisol of 167 nmol/L (N < 50) and a 24-hour urinary cortisol is 425 μg (N < 300 μg). Serum ACTH is 169 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Subsequently, a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows a serum cortisol level of 164 nmol/L (N < 50). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exogenous corticosteroid administration causes negative feedback on ACTH production in the pituitary gland, causing low ACTH levels and presenting as ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels (ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome) instead, which means the primary cause of her symptoms is ACTH production by either her pituitary gland or an ectopic focus.

B) INCORRECT:

A corticotropic pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) would result in secondary hypercortisolism due to increased ACTH production by the tumor. However, ACTH production by corticotropic pituitary adenomas is responsive to suppressive feedback by high doses of dexamethasone, and cortisol levels would decrease. Elevated cortisol levels in this patient following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test suggest a different cause for secondary hypercortisolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Excess cortisol production by an adrenal carcinoma would suppress pituitary secretion of ACTH, leading to low ACTH levels and ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels, meaning she has ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome from either a pituitary or ectopic source.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can manifest with fatigue, irregular menstrual cycles, weight gain, depression, and lower extremity swelling but we already know from her cortisol level and laboratory studies that she has Cushing syndrome which better explains these symptoms. Hypothyroidism does not cause ectopic ACTH production so this is not the underlying cause of her symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytomas may very rarely manifest with ectopic ACTH production. However, this patient does not have any of the classic symptoms of pheochromocytoma such as paroxysmal elevations in heart rate and blood pressure with palpitations or diaphoresis.

F) CORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is the most common cause of endogenous hypercortisolism from an ectopic source of ACTH. A history of smoking is the strongest risk factor for SCLC. Because SCLC is a pulmonary neuroendocrine tumor, it can produce hormones that are associated with paraneoplastic syndromes including Cushing syndrome, SIADH, and Lambert-Eaton syndrome. In Cushing syndrome due to SCLC, the affected cells produce ACTH, which is not suppressed by high cortisol and is resistant to negative feedback. Consequently, serum cortisol levels remain elevated following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test, as seen in this patient.

Other cancers which are less commonly associated with the secretion of ACTH or ACTH-like substances include renal cell cancer, bronchial and pancreatic carcinoid tumors, and medullary thyroid carcinomas.

G) INCORRECT:

Excess cortisol production by an adrenal adenoma would suppress pituitary secretion of ACTH, leading to low ACTH levels and ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels, meaning she has ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome from either a pituitary or ectopic source.
questions.hint: In a patient who is not on glucocorticoid therapy, serum cortisol levels that remain elevated following a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test are consistent with endogenous hypercortisolism. Elevated serum ACTH levels suggest secondary hypercortisolism, while elevated serum cortisol levels following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test indicate ectopic ACTH production.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of irregular menses and generalized fatigue for the past 4 months. Menses previously occurred at regular 25- to 29-day intervals and lasted for 5 days but now occur at 45- to 60-day intervals. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 146/100 mm Hg. Examination shows facial hair as well as comedones on the face and back. There are multiple ecchymotic patches on the trunk. Neurological examination shows weakness of the iliopsoas and biceps muscles bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,500/mm3


Platelet count
510,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

145 mEq/L


 K+

3.3 mEq/L


 Cl-

100 mEq/L


 Glucose
188 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cushing syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with menstrual changes, fatigue, acne, hirsutism, ecchymoses, hypertension, and proximal muscle weakness. Irregular menstrual cycles are likely due to the inhibitory effect of high circulating cortisol on gonadotropin release. Hyperglycemia is caused by cortisol stimulating gluconeogenesis, peripheral insulin resistance, and direct suppression of insulin release. Leukocytosis can occur as a result of demargination of neutrophils from vascular walls. Hypokalemia is due to the aldosterone-like effects of cortisol, which stimulates the excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, causing metabolic alkalosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism is one of the most common causes of secondary hypertension. It is caused by elevated circulating aldosterone levels, which result in increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the urine. Although this patient's blood pressure is elevated, her menstrual changes, fatigue, acne, hirsutism, ecchymoses, and proximal muscle weakness are not consistent with hyperaldosteronism.

C) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal glands, leads to increased sympathetic activity. Patients typically present with episodic hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis. Although this patient has elevated blood pressure, she does not have headaches. Furthermore, symptoms such as menstrual abnormalities, fatigue, acne, and hirsutism are not consistent with pheochromocytoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by high levels of circulating androgens, which leads to virilization, obesity, acne, and hirsutism. Although the clinical presentation of PCOS overlaps with Cushing syndrome, this patient's proximal muscle weakness, ecchymoses, hypertension, and leukocytosis make PCOS less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can present with weight gain, fatigue, menstrual cycle abnormalities, hypertension, muscle weakness, acne, and possibly hirsutism. However, constipation, dry skin, cold intolerance, and delayed relaxation of tendon reflexes would also be expected. Additionally, hypothyroidism would also not explain this patient's ecchymoses, leukocytosis, or hyperglycemia (hypoglycemia is possible instead).
questions.hint: A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test would help confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 9-kg (20-lb) weight gain over the past 12 months. She also has irregular menstrual cycles and difficulty sleeping. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. Menarche was at age of 13 years and her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She has 1-year history of hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. She drinks a glass of wine daily. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/86 mm Hg. Examination shows acne on the face and hair on the chin and around the umbilicus. The face has a rounded shape and is reddened. There are several smaller bruises on both forearms. This patient is most likely to have which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyponatremia can be caused by insufficient secretion of mineralocorticoids in patients with Addison disease. Individuals with Addison disease have symptoms of adrenal insufficiency, including weight loss, lethargy, intestinal complaints (nausea, vomiting, and/or diarrhea), hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and loss of axillary and pubic hair, none of which are present in this patient. Laboratory studies of this patient will most likely show hypernatremia, not hyponatremia, due to the mineralocorticoid effect of high levels of cortisol.

B) INCORRECT:

Periorbital and facial myxedema is a typical finding in patients with hypothyroidism. Although hypothyroidism can also manifest with weight gain, irregular menstrual cycles, fatigue, and hypertension, which are all seen here, other typical findings, including cold intolerance, constipation, cold, dry skin, and hair loss, are absent in this patient. Facial flushing and moon facies, along with acne and hirsutism, make another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased serum EPO is a typical finding in patients with chronic hypoxia due to obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Although OSA often manifests with difficulty sleeping, fatigue, obesity, hypertension, irregular menstrual cycles, and flushing (plethora due to secondary polycythemia), it would not explain the easily bruisable skin, moon facies, hirsutism, and acne in this patient. Hemoglobin may be increased in individuals with Cushing syndrome, but EPO levels are typically within normal limits.

D) CORRECT:

In individuals with Cushing syndrome, high levels of cortisol cause inhibition of calcitriol synthesis, leading to decreased bone mineral density and osteoporosis in approx. 50% of patients. Patients with Cushing syndrome are therefore at increased risk for pathological fractures and avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Other typical features of Cushing syndrome include insulin resistance (causing hyperglycemia), increased susceptibility to infections, lethargy, and depression.

Prolonged glucocorticoid therapy is the most common cause of Cushing syndrome, causing exogenous or iatrogenic Cushing syndrome. Causes of endogenous Cushing syndrome include adrenal adenomas, pituitary adenomas (Cushing disease), and paraneoplastic syndrome (e.g., due to small cell lung cancer).

E) INCORRECT:

Yellowish discoloration of the corneal margin indicates arcus senilis, which can be caused by lipid disorders. Although lipid disorders often manifest with obesity, as seen here, patients typically have other clinical features such as xanthelasmas and atherosclerosis, along with secondary diseases (e.g., coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, stroke), which are absent in this patient. Moreover, lipid disorders would not explain the irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, easily bruisable skin, moon facies, and facial flushing in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles are a typical finding in patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). PCOS may also manifest with obesity, irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, acne, and hypertension, which are all seen here. However, patients present more commonly with acanthosis nigricans than easily bruisable skin. Furthermore, disease onset of PCOS is typically during adolescence, whereas this patient is already in her thirties. Lastly, this patient's facial flushing and moon facies make another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Hirsutism, thin, easily bruisable skin (ecchymoses), moon facies (rounded facial shape), flushing of the face, acne, weight gain, irregular menstrual cycles, hypertension, and fatigue can all be explained by excess production of cortisol, making Cushing syndrome the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty sleeping and fatigue. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. She has had an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain over this period. She also reports decreased sexual desire and increased hair growth on her face and arms. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, increased pigmented hair over the chin and upper lip, and purple stretch marks on the abdomen. She has a prominent hump of fat over the base of the dorsum of her neck and decreased proximal muscle tone and strength. Serum studies show:


Na+

154 mEq/L


K+

2.8 mEq/L


Cl-

103 mEq/L


HCO3-

30 mEq/L


Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Glucose
236 mg/dL


ACTH

2 pg/mL (N = 7–50)


Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Since this patient has Cushing syndrome due to primary hypercortisolism, therapy with prednisolone is contraindicated because it would aggravate her condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Metyrapone, ketoconazole, and etomidate are drugs that suppress cortisol synthesis and are used in patients with nonresectable ACTH-producing tumors (e.g., advanced small cell carcinoma of the lung), which would cause an elevated ACTH. This patient has primary hypercortisolism caused by a cortisol-producing tumor, for which pharmacological therapy is not the most appropriate initial treatment.

C) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has primary hypercortisolism, which is typically caused by autonomous overproduction of cortisol by an adrenal tumor (most commonly adrenal adenoma). Excess cortisol production suppresses the pituitary secretion of ACTH, leading to low ACTH levels and ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, as seen here. The treatment of choice for patients with adrenocortical tumors is laparoscopic or open adrenalectomy. After surgical therapy, patients who develop adrenal insufficiency require lifelong glucocorticoid replacement therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of polychemotherapy and radiation is a curative treatment approach for patients with small cell lung cancer (SCLC) who have limited-stage disease. SCLC is frequently associated with paraneoplastic syndromes and is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing syndrome from an ectopic source of ACTH. In SCLC, the affected cells produce ACTH that is resistant to negative feedback of high cortisol, resulting in secondary hypercortisolism. This patient has primary hypercortisolism.

E) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is the treatment of choice in patients with corticotropic pituitary adenoma (i.e., Cushing disease). Although pituitary adenoma is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing syndrome, it would result in secondary hypercortisolism due to increased ACTH production by the tumor. This patient has primary hypercortisolism.
questions.hint: This patient has classic features of Cushing syndrome, including weight gain, hyperglycemia, proximal muscle weakness, menstrual cycle changes, truncal obesity, striae, hirsutism, and hypertension. This patient's hypernatremia and hypokalemia are most likely due to the mineralocorticoid effect of high levels of cortisol. Her low ACTH levels indicate primary hypercortisolism.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of weight gain over the past 3 months. During this period, he has gained 10 kg (22 lb) unintentionally. He also reports decreased sexual desire, oily skin, and sleeping difficulties. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. The patient appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, acne, and thin, easily bruisable skin with stretch marks on the abdomen. There is darkening of the mucous membranes and the skin creases. Examination of the muscles shows atrophy and weakness of proximal muscle groups. His serum glucose concentration is 240 mg/dL. Which of the following findings would most likely be present on imaging?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adrenal adenomas can also cause endogenous hypercortisolism, in which case it is referred to as ACTH-independent hypercortisolism (or primary hypercortisolism). However, hyperpigmentation of the skin creases and mucous membranes is not a feature of primary hypercortisolism. In addition, adrenal adenomas are rare; there is a much more common cause of endogenous hypercortisolism.

B) CORRECT:

Endogenous hypercortisolism is most often caused by a pituitary adenoma (approx. 75% of cases), in which case it is referred to as ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, or Cushing disease. This patient presents with the classic features of excess glucocorticoid production, including central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, proximal muscle weakness and atrophy, hypertension, and hyperglycemia. His hyperpigmentation (e.g., darkening of mucous membranes and skin creases) is a unique feature of Cushing disease that results from increased production of ACTH, which is cleaved from the same precursor as melanocyte-stimulating hormone.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased thyroid size can be seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis. Patients with hypothyroidism can present with weight gain, difficulty sleeping, and lethargy. Decreased thyroid hormone can also increase prolactin levels and lead to decreased libido, as seen in this patient, but other features in this patient, particularly the stretch marks, muscle atrophy, hyperpigmentation, and hyperglycemia, are more consistent with Cushing syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Multiple kidney cysts are seen in polycystic kidney disease (PKD), which can also cause hypertension. However, other symptoms such as abdominal and/or flank pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, and chronic renal failure would also be expected. Furthermore, hyperglycemia and hyperpigmentation are not seen in PKD, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Adrenal carcinomas can also cause endogenous hypercortisolism, in which case it is referred to as ACTH-independent hypercortisolism. Patients with adrenal carcinoma present similarly to those with benign lesions (either pituitary or adrenal in origin), with central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, and proximal muscle weakness and atrophy. However, adrenal carcinomas are rare in adults and would not be associated with hyperpigmentation.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can cause secondary hypercortisolism through ectopic ACTH production as a paraneoplastic syndrome. Although RCC is the most common type of kidney tumor in adults, it rarely presents as Cushing syndrome. Moreover, this patient does not have a history of hematuria or any other manifestations (flank pain or mass) consistent with RCC.

G) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer can lead to ectopic ACTH production as a paraneoplastic syndrome, which would also manifest with central obesity, acne, and thin, easily bruisable skin with stretch marks on the abdomen. As a smoker, this patient is at higher risk for lung cancer. However, symptoms of lung cancer like cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest pain are missing in this patient, and there are much more common causes of endogenous hypercortisolism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with the typical symptoms of hypercortisolism (e.g., central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, and proximal muscle weakness and atrophy). Since he has no history of prolonged glucocorticoid therapy, there must be an endogenous cause.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of unintentional weight gain, fatigue, and decreased sexual desire. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His blood pressure is 149/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity and abdominal striae. He has a prominent soft-tissue bulge at the dorsum of his neck. Laboratory studies show a 24-hour urinary free cortisol of 200 μg (N < 50) and a morning serum ACTH of 1 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the underlying etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CRH stimulation test can be used in patients with ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism to differentiate whether the source of excess ACTH production is pituitary (Cushing disease) or ectopic. If serum ACTH and cortisol levels increase further after CRH stimulation, Cushing disease is confirmed; minimal or no change in their levels suggests ectopic ACTH production. Since the patient presents with ACTH-independent hypercortisolism, this test would not be indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

ACTH stimulation test is used to test the response of the adrenal glands to ACTH in patients suspected of having adrenal insufficiency (e.g., hypocortisolism), such as Addison disease. Since this patient presents with hypercortisolism, this test would not be indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test can be used in the initial screening for hypercortisolism. In normal individuals, dexamethasone suppresses ACTH secretion and thus decreases the level of cortisol. However, in this patient, the diagnosis of hypercortisolism using a 24–hour urine sample as well as a decreased ACTH level in serum has already been established, indicating an ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. Therefore a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test would not be helpful in confirming the cause of his symptoms.

High-dose dexamethasone suppression test can be used in patients with ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism to differentiate whether the source of ACTH production is pituitary (Cushing disease) or ectopic.

D) INCORRECT:

Petrosal vein catheterization is performed in patients with suspected ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma if brain MRI studies are unable to identify pituitary adenoma but clinical suspicion is still high. However, ACTH levels in secondary hypercortisolism would either be normal or elevated, as opposed to this patient's low ACTH levels.

E) INCORRECT:

A chest CT would be helpful if small cell lung cancer, which can lead to paraneoplastic, ectopic ACTH production, and subsequent secondary hypercortisolism, were suspected. However, ectopic ACTH production would manifest with normal or elevated ACTH levels, as opposed to this patient's low ACTH. Also, this patient lacks other symptoms of lung cancer, such as cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest pain.

F) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms and laboratory findings consistent with ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome due to autonomous overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal gland. Once Cushing syndrome has been determined to be ACTH-independent, a thin-section CT or MRI of the adrenal glands should be performed to evaluate for adrenal mass. Common etiologies for excess adrenal cortisol production include adrenal adenoma, adrenal carcinoma, and adrenal hyperplasia.

Prolonged glucocorticoid therapy is the most common cause of hypercortisolism.

G) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain may be used to visualize pituitary masses in patients with suspected Cushing disease due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma (e.g., secondary hypercortisolism). However, ACTH levels in secondary hypercortisolism would either be normal or elevated, as opposed to this patient's low ACTH levels.
questions.hint: This patient presents with typical features of Cushing syndrome, including weight gain, truncal obesity, striae, hypertension, fatigue, and decreased sexual desire. High cortisol levels in conjunction with low ACTH levels indicate primary hypercortisolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, irregular menses, and recurrent respiratory infections for the past 6 months. Her blood pressure is 151/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a round face, thinning of the skin, and multiple bruises on her arms. Further studies confirm the diagnosis of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cushing disease is associated with weight gain rather than weight loss. Patients with Cushing disease have a characteristic pattern of weight gain and fat deposition in the neck (buffalo hump), trunk, and abdomen (central obesity), as well as the face (round, moon facies).

B) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilia is a hematologic finding associated with chronic adrenal insufficiency, not Cushing syndrome. This patient has a cortisol-secreting pituitary adenoma and clinical features of hypercortisolism – not hypocortisolism, as would be seen in adrenal insufficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Cushing disease is most commonly associated with hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia. Hypercortisolism raises blood glucose by increasing insulin resistance and hepatic uptake of glucose to be used in gluconeogenesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bitemporal hemianopsia is a complication of pituitary macroadenomas (size > 10 mm) such as prolactinoma, gonadotropinomas, somatotropinomas, and thyrotropinomas. Bitemporal hemianopsia is caused by compression of the optic nerve at the level of the optic chiasm. While this patient's hypercortisolism is due to a pituitary adenoma, she is unlikely to develop bitemporal hemianopsia, as Cushing disease is most commonly caused by microadenomas (size < 10 mm) rather than macroadenomas.

E) CORRECT:

Cushing disease is associated with pathological fractures due to osteoporosis. Excess cortisol inhibits calcitriol and osteoblast maturation while simultaneously increasing production of RANKL, which stimulates osteoclasts and results in increased levels of bone resorption. Other features of Cushing disease include cataracts, peptic ulcer disease, dyslipidemia, muscle atrophy/weakness, acne, hirsutism, and psychiatric conditions such as generalized anxiety disorder, major depressive disorder, and psychosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Cushing disease is associated with hypokalemia rather than hyperkalemia. Hypokalemia is caused by the mineralocorticoid effect of cortisol on aldosterone receptors, which stimulates sodium and water reabsorption (causing hypertension), potassium excretion, and metabolic alkalosis. Hyperkalemia is usually seen in hypocortisolism as part of primary adrenal insufficiency. This patient has hypercortisolism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with typical findings of hypercortisolism (e.g., moon facies, bruisable skin, irregular menstrual cycle, recurrent infections, hypertension) due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease).

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of unintentional weight gain of 5.5 kg (12.2 lb) and irregular menstrual cycles over the past 2 months. She does not take any medications. Her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, hyperpigmentation of the palmar creases, and violaceous scarring of the abdomen. Early morning serum cortisol levels are elevated and serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is within the reference range after a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of ACTH. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Benign adenoma of the adrenal medulla
Nodular hypertrophy of the zona reticularis
Bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata
Unilateral carcinoma of the adrenal cortex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pituitary gland atrophy is observed in Sheehan syndrome, which presents with hypopituitarism. The earliest presenting symptom is failure to lactate after delivery due to impaired prolactin secretion, which can also be followed by sequential development of secondary hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, and adrenal insufficiency. Even though this patient has menstrual irregularity, she does not have clinical features of hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency, nor risk factors for Sheehan syndrome (e.g., recent pregnancy), and her serum ACTH level does not align with hypopituitarism.

B) INCORRECT:

Benign adenoma of the adrenal medulla affects chromaffin cells, which are regulated by preganglionic sympathetic fibers. Pheochromocytoma is a chromaffin cell tumor that is mostly benign and affects the adrenal medulla in 90% of cases. Its clinical features include episodic hypertension, paroxysmal palpitation, headache, and pallor due to sympathetic hyperstimulation as a result of excess catecholamine secretion. This patient does not have any of these features.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with Cushing disease will have diffuse and bilateral zona reticularis hyperplasia (not hypertrophy) due to excessive ACTH-dependent adrenocortical stimulation.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with Cushing disease most likely has bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata due to excessive ACTH-dependent adrenocortical stimulation. In addition, excessive pituitary or ectopic ACTH production leads to development of hyperpigmentation in areas not normally exposed to the sun as seen in this patient's palmar crease. This results from increased collateral melanocyte stimulating hormone production, which is cleaved from the same precursor protein (proopiomelanocortin) as ACTH.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive cortisol secreted by an adrenal cortex tumor can cause many clinical features of Cushing syndrome, such as this patient's weight gain with central obesity, abdominal striae, hypertension, and irregular menses. However, unlike ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, adrenocortical cancer does not induce skin hyperpigmentation as there is no increased collateral melanocyte stimulating hormone secretion. Additionally, elevated cortisol would cause decreased ACTH levels (unlike in this patient), since cortisol suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis through a negative feedback loop.
questions.hint: This patient has signs of Cushing syndrome: weight gain with central obesity, abdominal striae, hypertension, hyperpigmentation, and irregular menses. A positive low-dose dexamethasone suppression test indicates hypercortisolism. A serum ACTH within the reference range in this context is considered abnormal, as ACTH secretion should physiologically be suppressed by elevated serum cortisol levels. Suppression of ACTH with high-dose dexamethasone confirms increased ACTH production from the pituitary gland (Cushing disease).

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive headache and fatigue for the past 2 months. One year ago, she was diagnosed with Cushing syndrome, which was ultimately treated with bilateral adrenalectomy. Current medications are hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone. Examination shows generalized hyperpigmentation of the skin and bitemporal visual field defects. Serum studies show an ACTH concentration of 1250 pg/mL (N = 20–100). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pharmacotherapy with dopamine agonists (e.g., bromocriptine, cabergoline) is the first-line treatment of prolactinomas. Dopamine inhibits pituitary synthesis and release of prolactin, thereby normalizing serum prolactin levels and reducing tumor size. Patients with macroprolactinomas may present with headache and bitemporal hemianopsia, as seen here. However, hyperpigmentation is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, this patient lacks the classic features of hyperprolactinemia, such as gynecomastia, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and menopausal symptoms (e.g., amenorrhea, irregular menses, vaginal atrophy).

B) INCORRECT:

Metyrapone inhibits cortisol synthesis in the adrenal cortex and can be used to differentiate primary versus secondary (or tertiary) adrenal insufficiency as part of the metyrapone stimulation test. However, this test requires the presence of an adrenal gland and therefore has no value in this patient who underwent bilateral adrenalectomy.

C) CORRECT:

Radiotherapy of the pituitary is a first-line treatment option for patients with Nelson syndrome, a complication that can occur following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing syndrome. Nelson syndrome is thought to result from increased growth of preexisting corticotrophic pituitary microadenomas, which occurs with reduced glucocorticoid feedback inhibition. The hyperpigmentation seen in this patient is due to a combination of excessive melanocyte-stimulating hormone production as a byproduct of ACTH synthesis, and excessively elevated levels of plasma ACTH that stimulate melanocytes to produce melanin. This patient's progressive headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, nausea, and vomiting are due to intracranial mass effect secondary to the growth of corticotrophic pituitary adenomas.

Transsphenoidal surgical excision of the adenoma is the other first-line treatment option for patients with Nelson syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Reduction of glucocorticoid (e.g., hydrocortisone) dosage is indicated in patients with iatrogenic Cushing syndrome due to excessive exogenous glucocorticoid intake. In this condition, high circulating blood levels of (exogenous) glucocorticoids lead to feedback inhibition of pituitary ACTH production. This patient, however, presents with elevated ACTH levels. Moreover, hyperpigmentation of the skin, progressive headache, and bitemporal hemianopsia are inconsistent with iatrogenic hypercortisolism. Furthermore, this patient lacks characteristic features of Cushing syndrome such as central obesity, abnormal fat deposits around the face (“moon facies”), abdominal striae, proximal muscle weakness, and easy bruising.

E) INCORRECT:

Up to 10% of patients with small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) develop paraneoplastic syndrome, which may include ectopic production of ACTH (i.e., secondary hypercortisolism). This patient presents with elevated ACTH levels, skin hyperpigmentation, and fatigue, all of which can be seen in secondary hypercortisolism. However, she has no other signs, symptoms, or significant history (e.g., history of cigarette smoking) that suggest a lung malignancy. In addition, progressive headache and bitemporal visual field defects are not consistent with SCLC.
questions.hint: This patient with Cushing syndrome was treated with a bilateral adrenal resection. She now presents with skin hyperpigmentation, progressive headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, and a massively elevated ACTH level, which is concerning for Nelson syndrome.

Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the underlying etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain may be used to visualize pituitary masses in patients with suspected Cushing disease due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma (e.g., secondary hypercortisolism). However, ACTH levels in secondary hypercortisolism would either be normal or elevated, as opposed to this patient's low ACTH levels.

B) INCORRECT:

ACTH stimulation test is used to test the response of the adrenal glands to ACTH in patients suspected of having adrenal insufficiency (e.g., hypocortisolism), such as Addison disease. Since this patient presents with hypercortisolism, this test would not be indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

CRH stimulation test can be used in patients with ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism to differentiate whether the source of excess ACTH production is pituitary (Cushing disease) or ectopic. If serum ACTH and cortisol levels increase further after CRH stimulation, Cushing disease is confirmed; minimal or no change in their levels suggests ectopic ACTH production. Since the patient presents with ACTH-independent hypercortisolism, this test would not be indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test can be used in the initial screening or confirmation of hypercortisolism. However, in this patient, the diagnosis of hypercortisolism using a 24–hour urine sample and late-night serum cortisol study has already been established, and the decreased serum ACTH level indicates ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test would not help confirm the cause of her hypercortisolism.

High-dose dexamethasone suppression test can be used in patients with ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism to differentiate whether the source of ACTH production is pituitary (Cushing disease) or ectopic.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with findings consistent with ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome due to autonomous overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal gland. Once Cushing syndrome has been determined to be ACTH-independent, a thin-section CT or MRI of the adrenal glands should be performed to evaluate for an adrenal mass. Common etiologies for excess adrenal cortisol production include adrenal adenoma, adrenal carcinoma, and adrenal hyperplasia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with typical features of Cushing syndrome, including weight gain, truncal obesity, striae, hypertension, fatigue, and decreased sexual desire. High cortisol levels in conjunction with low ACTH levels indicate primary hypercortisolism.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman with a history of drug-resistant HIV infection is evaluated for fatigue and a weight gain of 4.5 kg during the past 4 months. On the basis of her previous HIV drug-resistance pattern, she has been prescribed an antiretroviral regimen consisting of daily tenofovir, daily emtricitabine, and twice-daily ritonavir-boosted darunavir. She has a CD4 count of 456 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600) and an undetectable HIV viral load. She also takes lisinopril for hypertension and inhaled fluticasone for mild asthma.
The patient’s blood pressure is 168/95 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a dorsocervical fat pad. A random glucose level is 195 mg/dL (reference range, <140).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain CT of the adrenal glands
Schedule MRI of the pituitary gland

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tenofovir does not interact with glucocorticoids and does not need to be discontinued. If this patient's fluticasone is discontinued, there is no need to change the antiretroviral regimen.

B) CORRECT:

The HIV protease inhibitor ritonavir is a potent inhibitor of the cytochrome P-450 3A4 enzyme, which also metabolizes fluticasone. Coadministration of protease inhibitors with oral or inhaled fluticasone has been associated with the development of iatrogenic Cushing syndrome. Therefore, these drugs should generally not be coadministered.

Symptoms and signs of Cushing syndrome include weight gain, facial plethora, moon facies, buffalo hump, easy bruising, hypertension, impaired glucose tolerance, and emotional lability. Because of its long half-life and lipophilic properties, fluticasone is more likely to accumulate systemically than beclomethasone, which can be used with caution to treat asthma in a patient who uses a protease inhibitor.

Another complication of coadministration of fluticasone and ritonavir is suppression of endogenous adrenal function. As ritonavir blocks fluticasone metabolism, levels of fluticasone will increase and exert negative feedback on adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion from the pituitary gland. The lack of the trophic effect of ACTH on the adrenal glands over weeks and months can lead to adrenal gland atrophy. If fluticasone is stopped, this may leave the patient with no source of glucocorticoid activity, which can lead to a presentation of adrenal insufficiency.

Key learning point: When taken by a patient who uses an inhaled glucocorticoid, protease inhibitors can lead to Cushing syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

The elevated blood glucose level will probably improve once the fluticasone is stopped. Additional investigations for hypercortisolemia (such as free cortisol measurement and imaging of the pituitary or adrenal glands) are unnecessary when iatrogenic Cushing syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The elevated blood glucose level will probably improve once the fluticasone is stopped. Additional investigations for hypercortisolemia (such as free cortisol measurement and imaging of the pituitary or adrenal glands) are unnecessary when iatrogenic Cushing syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

The elevated blood glucose level will probably improve once the fluticasone is stopped. Additional investigations for hypercortisolemia (such as free cortisol measurement and imaging of the pituitary or adrenal glands) are unnecessary when iatrogenic Cushing syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman is hospitalized for severe acute back pain that developed while she was gardening. She reports no trauma but does report gaining approximately 3 kg during the past year and feeling fatigued. She has a history of epilepsy, for which she takes phenytoin, and a humerus fracture sustained during a generalized tonic-clonic seizure 3 years ago.
Her blood pressure is 139/89 mm Hg, her heart rate is 94 beats per minute, and her BMI is 24.3. There is point tenderness on palpation over the lumbar spine and some mild acne on the upper back. There is no hirsutism.
Plain radiography of the lumbar spine is performed (figure). The patient is hospitalized.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of midnight salivary cortisol before discharge
Remeasurement of an 8 a.m. cortisol level in 8 weeks
A 24-hour urine collection for measurement of free cortisol 2 weeks after discharge

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute pain and stress of hospitalization may be associated with elevations in the cortisol level. This could make unreliable the interpretation of salivary cortisol. Therefore, the evaluation is best postponed until after the patient has recovered from the stress of hospitalization.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute pain and stress of hospitalization may be associated with elevations in the cortisol level. This could make unreliable the interpretation of cortisol levels after a dexamethasone-suppression test. Therefore, the evaluation is best postponed until after the patient has recovered from the stress of hospitalization.

In addition, she is taking phenytoin, which accelerates dexamethasone metabolism, such that a 1-mg dexamethasone-suppression test would not be informative.

C) INCORRECT:

After discharge, a 24-hour urine free cortisol measurement or a midnight salivary cortisol measurement would be the most appropriate test to rule out Cushing syndrome. An 8 a.m. cortisol measurement is not sufficiently sensitive to be routinely used for this purpose.

D) CORRECT:

A nonelderly woman who has multiple vertebral compression fractures should be evaluated for secondary causes of osteoporosis, including Cushing syndrome. However, the acute pain and stress of hospitalization may be associated with elevations in the cortisol level. This could make unreliable the interpretation of random cortisol, salivary cortisol, or cortisol levels after a dexamethasone-suppression test. Therefore, the evaluation is best postponed until after the patient has recovered from the stress of hospitalization.

After discharge, a 24-hour urine free cortisol measurement or a midnight salivary cortisol measurement would be the most appropriate test to rule out Cushing syndrome.

In this patient, the osteoporosis may also be secondary to phenytoin use, which has been associated with reduction in bone mass.

Key learning point: The best timing of evaluation for Cushing syndrome in a hospitalized patient is after discharge and recovery from the stress of hospitalization.

E) INCORRECT:

Because innocuous nodules of the adrenal glands are common, the adrenal glands should not be visualized on imaging, such as CT, unless hypercortisolemia is confirmed.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman reports to the emergency department with a 3-month history of increasing difficulty getting out of chairs, climbing stairs, and managing daily activities. She can no longer get out of bed herself and reports weakness, easy bruising, worsening of her chronic cough, and weight loss of 9.1 kg.
Her medical history is notable only for osteoarthritis of the knee, for which she takes ibuprofen as needed, and mild contact dermatitis controlled with the use of over-the-counter hydrocortisone lotion. She reports no use of diuretics. She is retired, has smoked 10 cigarettes per day for the past 50 years, and drinks one to two alcoholic drinks per week.
On physical examination, her blood pressure is 163/88 mm Hg. She is thin, has marked proximal muscle weakness, and has several bruises on her forearms and shins.
Laboratory evaluation reveals the following levels:



Patient value
Reference range



Potassium (mEq/liter)
2.2
3.5–5.0


Sodium (mEq/liter)
143
136–145



Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
34
21–30


Chloride (mEq/liter)
98
98–106



Fasting glucose (mg/dL)
193
70–100


What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism is a genetic disease and would not have its onset at an older age.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone cream is not very potent, so its use is unlikely to be associated with the rapidly progressive features of Cushing syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

An ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma or a cortisol-producing adrenocortical adenoma can cause Cushing syndrome, but they are usually slower to progress than ectopic ACTH production and more likely to be associated with weight gain rather than weight loss. In these two conditions, signs and symptoms of cortisol excess (e.g., weight gain, centripetal adiposity, and proximal myopathy) dominate the clinical presentation. Hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis are not features of mild or moderate hypercortisolism.

D) INCORRECT:

An ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma or a cortisol-producing adrenocortical adenoma can cause Cushing syndrome, but they are usually slower to progress than ectopic ACTH production and more likely to be associated with weight gain rather than weight loss. In these two conditions, signs and symptoms of cortisol excess (e.g., weight gain, centripetal adiposity, and proximal myopathy) dominate the clinical presentation. Hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis are not features of mild or moderate hypercortisolism.

E) CORRECT:

Ectopic production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is seen in many tumors, particularly small-cell lung carcinomas, and occurs in patients with rapidly progressive Cushing syndrome. There may be modest physical findings of cortisol excess, but metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hyperglycemia) dominate the clinical presentation because of the severe and usually sudden onset of hypercortisolism. There are multiple potential causes of the patient’s hypokalemia and hyperglycemia. However, in cases where symptoms are rapidly progressive and associated with weight loss and marked metabolic abnormalities, ectopic ACTH production is the most likely diagnosis. The weight loss is caused by the underlying cancer.

Key learning point: New-onset metabolic abnormalities associated with Cushing syndrome (e.g., hypokalemia or hyperglycemia) with only modest findings of cortisol excess on physical examination is most consistent with ectopic production of adrenocorticotropic hormone.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man reports a 3-week history of progressive profound muscle weakness. He can no longer get out of a car or climb stairs. He also reports back pain and weight gain of about 3 kg. Imaging reveals hypodense lesions in several thoracic vertebrae, and biopsy is consistent with a neuroendocrine tumor. Further evaluation identifies a 2-cm right lung mass; pathology is consistent with a carcinoid tumor.
On examination, his blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg, his heart rate is 65 beats per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 95% while he is breathing ambient air. His proximal muscle strength is 3/5 bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. He has slight erythema of the cheeks.
Noncontrast CT of the brain is unremarkable.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
140
136–145


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
36
21–30



Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.0
3.5–5.0


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
15
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.8–1.3



Glucose (mg/dL)
260
70–100


Which one of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) syndrome is characterized by the ectopic secretion of ACTH from a nonpituitary tumor. ACTH syndrome may manifest with an apparently abrupt onset of physical and metabolic consequences of severe hypercortisolism, including weakness, especially of the proximal muscles, and worsening hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypokalemia or metabolic alkalosis. Physical findings include proximal muscle weakness, facial plethora, moon facies, increased supraclavicular fat, ecchymoses, and wide purple striae on the abdomen.

The ectopic ACTH syndrome occurs most frequently with carcinoid tumors and small-cell lung neoplasms. The most effective treatment is bilateral adrenalectomy or inhibition of cortisol production by means of oral agents such as metyrapone.

Key learning point: A patient with a metastatic carcinoid tumor who presents with symptoms and physical findings suggestive of Cushing syndrome is most likely to have ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated metanephrine or normetanephrine levels are associated with pheochromocytoma, characterized by hypertension with headache, anxiety, or diaphoresis.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate levels are seen in patients with adrenocortical carcinoma or in women with hyperandrogenic states, such as the polycystic ovary syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevation in insulin-like growth factor levels causes acromegaly.

E) INCORRECT:

High gastrin levels are indicative of gastrinoma, which can cause ulcers in the stomach and small intestine.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and hypertension presents with polydipsia, nausea, weakness, polyphagia, and polyuria. Two months earlier, she was diagnosed with a bronchial carcinoid tumor.
Laboratory findings are normal except for the following results: potassium 2.3 mEq/liter (reference range, 3.5–5.0), bicarbonate 38 mEq/liter (21–30), and fasting glucose 405 mg/dL (70–100).
Which one of the following diagnostic tests should be performed next?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-Hu antibodies are polyclonal IgG autoantibodies directed against proteins of the Hu antigen family. They are associated with paraneoplastic sensory neuropathy and encephalomyelitis, most commonly in small-cell lung cancer and rarely in sarcoma and neuroblastoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the glycated hemoglobin level can indicate the degree of hyperglycemia, it will not clarify the cause of the hyperglycemia.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s findings are consistent with cortisol excess from adrenocorticotropic hormone-associated paraneoplastic syndrome. Bronchial carcinoid tumors are among the most common causes of paraneoplastic Cushing syndrome.

Cushing syndrome is often associated with hyperglycemia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

Cushing syndrome is diagnosed by demonstrating evidence of hypercortisolemia through performance of an overnight dexamethasone suppression test, measurement of 24-hour urinary free cortisol, or measurement of a midnight salivary cortisol. At least two of these tests are generally performed before confirming a diagnosis of Cushing syndrome. For the overnight dexamethasone test, the morning cortisol level is checked after administering 1 mg of dexamethasone at 11 p.m. the night before. The differential diagnosis of Cushing syndrome can be narrowed by measuring serum adrenocorticotrophic hormone; an elevated level indicates either Cushing disease (pituitary adenoma) or ectopic hormone production.

Key learning point: The best laboratory test to diagnose an adrenocorticotropic hormone-associated paraneoplastic syndrome is an overnight dexamethasone suppression test or a 24-hour urinary free cortisol test.

D) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid hormone-related peptide is commonly secreted by tumors. Its measurement is not indicated in the absence of hypercalcemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Stool fat estimation is a diagnostic test for fat malabsorption conditions, not paraneoplastic syndrome.

He also reports back pain and weight gain of about (3 kg) (6.6-lb). Imaging reveals hypodense lesions in several thoracic vertebrae, and biopsy is consistent with a neuroendocrine tumor. Further evaluation identifies a 2-cm right lung mass; pathology is consistent with a carcinoid tumor. Blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg, pulse is 65/min, and his oxygen saturation is 95% while he is breathing ambient air. Proximal muscle strength is 3/5 bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. He has slight erythema of the cheeks. Noncontrast CT of the brain is unremarkable. Serum findings include the following levels:

A) INCORRECT:

Increased dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate levels are seen in patients with adrenocortical carcinoma or in women with hyperandrogenic states, such as polycystic ovarian syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevation in insulin-like growth factor levels causes acromegaly.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated metanephrine or normetanephrine levels are associated with pheochromocytoma, characterized by hypertension with headache, anxiety, or diaphoresis.

D) CORRECT:

Ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) syndrome is characterized by the ectopic secretion of ACTH from a nonpituitary tumor. ACTH syndrome may manifest with an apparently abrupt onset of physical and metabolic consequences of severe hypercortisolism, including weakness, especially of the proximal muscles, and worsening hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypokalemia or metabolic alkalosis. Physical findings include proximal muscle weakness, facial plethora, moon facies, increased supraclavicular fat, ecchymoses, and wide purple striae on the abdomen.

The ectopic ACTH syndrome occurs most frequently with carcinoid tumors and small-cell lung neoplasms. The most effective treatment is bilateral adrenalectomy or inhibition of cortisol production by means of oral agents such as metyrapone.

Key learning point: A patient with a metastatic carcinoid tumor who presents with symptoms and physical findings suggestive of Cushing syndrome is most likely to have ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the office because of irregular menses and generalized fatigue for the past 4 months. Menses previously occurred at regular 25- to 29-day intervals but now occur at 45- to 60-day intervals. Body mass index is 37 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 146/100 mm Hg. Examination shows facial hair as well as comedones on the face and back. There are multiple ecchymotic patches on the trunk. Neurological examination shows weakness of the iliopsoas and biceps muscles bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,500/mm3


Serum



 Na+

145 mEq/L


 K+

3.3 mEq/L


 Glucose
188 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cushing syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with menstrual changes, fatigue, acne, hirsutism, ecchymoses, hypertension, and proximal muscle weakness. Irregular menstrual cycles are likely due to the inhibitory effect of high circulating cortisol on gonadotropin release. Hyperglycemia is caused by cortisol stimulating gluconeogenesis, peripheral insulin resistance, and direct suppression of insulin release. Leukocytosis can occur as a result of demargination of neutrophils from vascular walls. Hypokalemia is due to the aldosterone-like effects of cortisol, which stimulates the excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, causing metabolic alkalosis.

Key learning point: Cushing syndrome is characterized by central obesity, hypertension, hyperglycemia, proximal muscle weakness, hirsutism, acne, easy bruising, and menstrual irregularities due to chronic excess glucocorticoids.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism is one of the most common causes of secondary hypertension. It is caused by elevated circulating aldosterone levels, which result in increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the urine. Although this patient's blood pressure is elevated, her menstrual changes, fatigue, acne, hirsutism, ecchymoses, and proximal muscle weakness are not consistent with hyperaldosteronism.

C) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal glands, leads to increased sympathetic activity. Patients typically present with episodic hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis. Although this patient has elevated blood pressure, she does not have headaches. Furthermore, symptoms such as menstrual abnormalities, fatigue, acne, and hirsutism are not consistent with pheochromocytoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by high levels of circulating androgens, which leads to virilization, obesity, acne, and hirsutism. Although the clinical presentation of PCOS overlaps with Cushing syndrome, this patient's proximal muscle weakness, ecchymoses, hypertension, and leukocytosis make PCOS less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can present with weight gain, fatigue, menstrual cycle abnormalities, hypertension, muscle weakness, acne, and possibly hirsutism. However, constipation, dry skin, cold intolerance, and delayed relaxation of tendon reflexes would also be expected. Additionally, hypothyroidism would also not explain this patient's ecchymoses, leukocytosis, or hyperglycemia (hypoglycemia is possible instead).
questions.hint: A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test would help confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-month history of difficulty sleeping and fatigue. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. She has had an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain over this period. She also reports decreased sexual desire and increased hair growth on her face and arms. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, increased pigmented hair over the chin and upper lip, and purple stretch marks on the abdomen. She has a prominent hump of fat over the base of the dorsum of her neck and decreased proximal muscle tone and strength. Serum studies show:


Na+

154 mEq/L


K+

2.8 mEq/L


Cl-

103 mEq/L


HCO3-

30 mEq/L


Glucose
236 mg/dL


ACTH

2 pg/mL (N = 7–50)


Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Since this patient has Cushing syndrome due to primary hypercortisolism, therapy with prednisolone is contraindicated because it would aggravate her condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Metyrapone, ketoconazole, and etomidate are drugs that suppress cortisol synthesis and are used in patients with nonresectable ACTH-producing tumors (e.g., advanced small cell carcinoma of the lung), which would cause an elevated ACTH. This patient has primary hypercortisolism caused by a cortisol-producing tumor, for which pharmacological therapy is not the most appropriate initial treatment.

C) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has primary hypercortisolism, which is typically caused by autonomous overproduction of cortisol by an adrenal tumor (most commonly adrenal adenoma). Excess cortisol production suppresses the pituitary secretion of ACTH, leading to low ACTH levels and ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, as seen here. The treatment of choice for patients with adrenocortical tumors is laparoscopic or open adrenalectomy. After surgical therapy, patients who develop adrenal insufficiency require lifelong glucocorticoid replacement therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of polychemotherapy and radiation is a curative treatment approach for patients with small cell lung cancer (SCLC) who have limited-stage disease. SCLC is frequently associated with paraneoplastic syndromes and is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing syndrome from an ectopic source of ACTH. In SCLC, the affected cells produce ACTH that is resistant to negative feedback of high cortisol, resulting in secondary hypercortisolism. This patient has primary hypercortisolism.

E) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is the treatment of choice in patients with corticotropic pituitary adenoma (i.e., Cushing disease). Although pituitary adenoma is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing syndrome, it would result in secondary hypercortisolism due to increased ACTH production by the tumor. This patient has primary hypercortisolism.
questions.hint: This patient has classic features of Cushing syndrome, including weight gain, hyperglycemia, proximal muscle weakness, menstrual cycle changes, truncal obesity, striae, hirsutism, and hypertension. This patient's hypernatremia and hypokalemia are most likely due to the mineralocorticoid effect of high levels of cortisol. Her low ACTH levels indicate primary hypercortisolism.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of weight gain over the past 3 months. During this period, he has gained 10 kg (22 lb) unintentionally. He also reports decreased sexual desire, oily skin, and sleeping difficulties. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, acne, and thin, easily bruisable skin with stretch marks on the abdomen. There is darkening of the mucous membranes and the skin creases. Examination of the muscles shows atrophy and weakness of proximal muscle groups. His serum glucose concentration is 240 mg/dL. Which of the following findings would most likely be present on imaging?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Endogenous hypercortisolism is most often caused by a pituitary adenoma (approx. 75% of cases), in which case it is referred to as ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, or Cushing disease. This patient presents with the classic features of excess glucocorticoid production, including central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, proximal muscle weakness and atrophy, hypertension, and hyperglycemia. His hyperpigmentation (e.g., darkening of mucous membranes and skin creases) is a unique feature of Cushing disease that results from increased production of ACTH, which is cleaved from the same precursor as melanocyte-stimulating hormone.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased thyroid size can be seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis. Patients with hypothyroidism can present with weight gain, difficulty sleeping, and lethargy. Decreased thyroid hormone can also increase prolactin levels and lead to decreased libido, as seen in this patient, but other features in this patient, particularly the stretch marks, muscle atrophy, hyperpigmentation, and hyperglycemia, are more consistent with Cushing syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Adrenal carcinomas can also cause endogenous hypercortisolism, in which case it is referred to as ACTH-independent hypercortisolism. Patients with adrenal carcinoma present similarly to those with benign lesions (either pituitary or adrenal in origin), with central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, and proximal muscle weakness and atrophy. However, adrenal carcinomas are rare in adults and would not be associated with hyperpigmentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can cause secondary hypercortisolism through ectopic ACTH production as a paraneoplastic syndrome. Although RCC is the most common type of kidney tumor in adults, it rarely presents as Cushing syndrome. Moreover, this patient does not have a history of hematuria or any other manifestations (flank pain or mass) consistent with RCC.

E) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer can lead to ectopic ACTH production as a paraneoplastic syndrome, which would also manifest with central obesity, acne, and thin, easily bruisable skin with stretch marks on the abdomen. However, symptoms of lung cancer like cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest pain are missing in this patient, and there are much more common causes of endogenous hypercortisolism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with the typical symptoms of hypercortisolism (e.g., central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, and proximal muscle weakness and atrophy). Since he has no history of prolonged glucocorticoid therapy, there must be an endogenous cause.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with progressive weight gain, purple abdominal striae, and hypertension is found to have elevated cortisol levels. After CRH administration, cortisol levels markedly increase. Which cause best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adrenal cortisol-secreting adenomas cause ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, leading to suppressed ACTH levels. These tumors do not respond to CRH stimulation, unlike the ACTH-dependent mechanism indicated by the cortisol increase after CRH administration.

B) INCORRECT:

Ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors cause cortisol excess but typically lack CRH receptors, resulting in no significant cortisol increase after CRH administration. These tumors often present with rapid symptom onset and hypokalemia, which are not noted here.

C) INCORRECT:

Exogenous steroid use suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, leading to decreased ACTH and adrenal atrophy. CRH stimulation would not significantly increase cortisol levels, unlike the marked increase seen here, indicating an endogenous source of hypercortisolism.

D) CORRECT:

In a pituitary adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-secreting adenoma, corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) administration leads to a marked increase in ACTH and cortisol levels. This response is due to the adenoma's retained sensitivity to CRH, distinguishing it from other causes of hypercortisolism. The pituitary adenoma's CRH responsiveness is a key feature in diagnosing Cushing disease, where the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis remains responsive to CRH stimulation, resulting in increased cortisol production.

Key learning point: Corticotrophin-releasing hormone (CRH) is a key hormone involved in the neuro-hormonal stress response, initiating the HPA axis cascade that leads to cortisol release.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents with progressive weight gain, facial rounding, and purple striae on her abdomen for six months. She also notes proximal muscle weakness. She denies taking any exogenous glucocorticoids (see lab results).

Blood pressure
158/94 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Cortisol 1 hr after cosynoptrin
550 nmol/L
> 498 nmol/L


ACTH
0 pmol/L
2 - 11 pmol/L


Saliva




 Midnight salivary cortisol
250 nmol/L
< 30 nmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to determine the cause of this patient’s hypercortisolism?

choices.text: CT scan of the adrenal glands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inferior petrosal sinus sampling distinguishes pituitary from ectopic ACTH sources in ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome. The patient's suppressed ACTH level indicates an ACTH-independent cause, likely adrenal, making this procedure unnecessary.

B) CORRECT:

The patient exhibits hypercortisolism with elevated midnight salivary cortisol and undetectable adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), indicating ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This suggests an adrenal source, such as an adenoma, hyperplasia, or carcinoma. A CT scan of the adrenal glands is essential for identifying and characterizing adrenal lesions, providing details on size, shape, and attenuation. This imaging helps differentiate benign from malignant lesions, guiding management.

Key learning point: In ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, characterized by low ACTH levels, the next diagnostic step is imaging of the adrenal glands to identify potential adrenal sources of excess cortisol production.

C) INCORRECT:

Pituitary MRI is indicated for ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism, where ACTH levels are normal or elevated, suggesting a pituitary adenoma. The suppressed ACTH level in this patient indicates an adrenal source, making pituitary imaging unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test differentiates ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome sources. This patient has undetectable ACTH, indicating ACTH-independent hypercortisolism, typically adrenal in origin. The test is not useful without measurable ACTH.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with progressive weight gain, rounding of the face, wide purple striae on the abdomen, and worsening fatigue. He has been using potent topical steroid cream daily for severe plaque psoriasis over the past 14 months. He denies any use of systemic or inhaled glucocorticoids. Physical examination reveals central obesity, a dorsocervical fat pad, thin skin over the dorsal hands, easy bruising, and mild proximal muscle weakness (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Glucose, random
9.8 mmol/L
3.9 - 5.5 mmol/L


Cortisol 8 a.m.
85 nmol/L
138 - 635 nmol/L


ACTH
1 pmol/L
2 - 11 pmol/L



Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Excess exogenous glucocorticoid from topical therapy
Ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone secretion from a small cell lung tumor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A primary adrenal neoplasm causes elevated cortisol levels with suppressed ACTH due to autonomous cortisol secretion. This patient's low cortisol and ACTH levels suggest suppression from exogenous glucocorticoid use, not an adrenal neoplasm.

B) INCORRECT:

A pituitary corticotroph adenoma leads to elevated ACTH and cortisol levels. This patient's suppressed cortisol and ACTH levels indicate negative feedback from exogenous glucocorticoid use, not a pituitary adenoma.

C) CORRECT:

Prolonged use of potent topical steroids can lead to systemic absorption, causing iatrogenic Cushing syndrome. This condition manifests with central obesity, a rounded face, dorsocervical fat pad, thin skin, easy bruising, purple striae, and proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory findings typically show hyperglycemia, suppressed endogenous cortisol production, and low adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) levels due to negative feedback on the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. These clinical and laboratory features indicate that excess glucocorticoids from topical therapy are responsible for the observed syndrome.

Key learning point: Iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome can occur from the use of exogenous steroids, including potent topical steroids, and is characterized by low ACTH and cortisol levels due to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic ACTH secretion, such as from small cell lung cancer, results in elevated ACTH and cortisol levels. This patient's low cortisol and ACTH levels indicate suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, consistent with exogenous glucocorticoid use, not ectopic ACTH production.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman presents with a 7-month history of abdominal weight gain, muscle weakness, and easy bruising. She notes increased facial fullness and recent worsening of her hypertension. Physical examination shows moon facies and wide purplish striae. An abdominal imaging study demonstrates a 3-cm nodule in the left adrenal gland (see lab results and report).

Blood pressure
160/90 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Cortisol 8 a.m.
800 nmol/L
138 - 635 nmol/L


ACTH
0.2 pmol/L
2 - 11 pmol/L



Low-dose overnight dexamethasone suppression test: No suppression of cortisol
Which of the following is the most appropriate management to address her condition?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the left adrenal nodule

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient exhibits signs of Cushing syndrome, including abdominal weight gain, muscle weakness, and moon facies. The elevated cortisol level and suppressed adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) indicate ACTH-independent hypercortisolism. The lack of suppression on the low-dose dexamethasone test and the presence of a 3-cm adrenal nodule suggest an adrenal adenoma secreting cortisol. Surgical resection of the adrenal nodule is the definitive treatment, addressing the source of cortisol excess and preventing complications associated with prolonged hypercortisolism.

Key learning point: In ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome due to an adrenal adenoma, surgical excision of the adrenal mass is the most appropriate management.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilateral adrenalectomy is reserved for cases with bilateral adrenal hyperplasia or refractory hypercortisolism. This patient has a solitary adrenal nodule with suppressed ACTH, indicating unilateral adrenal involvement. Removing both adrenal glands would lead to adrenal insufficiency, requiring lifelong hormone replacement.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI of the sella turcica is used to evaluate pituitary adenomas in ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome. However, this patient has suppressed ACTH levels, indicating an adrenal source of cortisol excess. The identified adrenal nodule further supports an adrenal etiology, making pituitary imaging unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole inhibits cortisol synthesis and is used for temporary control of hypercortisolism or when surgery is contraindicated. In this patient, the adrenal nodule is the source of cortisol excess, and surgical resection is the preferred treatment. Ketoconazole does not address the underlying adrenal lesion and carries risks like hepatotoxicity.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents with a 10-month history of progressive weight gain, easy bruising, and fatigue. She reports no exogenous steroid use. Physical examination reveals multiple ecchymoses over her arms and wide, purple striae on the abdomen (see lab results).

Blood pressure
150/95 mm Hg



Test
