520 nmol/24 h
30 - 220 nmol/24 h


Cortisol 1 hr after cosynoptrin
520 nmol/L
> 498 nmol/L


ACTH
15 pmol/L
2 - 11 pmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient’s condition?

choices.text: CT scan of the adrenal glands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inferior petrosal sinus sampling differentiates between pituitary and ectopic ACTH sources when non-invasive tests are inconclusive. The mildly elevated ACTH level and clinical presentation suggest a pituitary adenoma. MRI of the pituitary is the next step, with inferior petrosal sinus sampling reserved for unclear cases after imaging.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms and elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol suggest endogenous hypercortisolism. The elevated adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) level indicates an ACTH-dependent cause, with a pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) being the most common. MRI of the pituitary is the preferred method for detecting microadenomas, providing high-resolution imaging of the sellar region. This imaging helps localize the source of ACTH excess, guiding further management.

Key learning point: In ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome, an MRI of the pituitary is the appropriate next step to evaluate for a pituitary adenoma, which is the most common cause of this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

CT imaging of the adrenal glands is used when ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome is suspected, characterized by autonomous cortisol production and suppressed ACTH levels. The elevated ACTH in this patient suggests an ACTH-dependent cause, making adrenal imaging unnecessary for localizing hypercortisolism.

D) INCORRECT:

The CRH stimulation test distinguishes pituitary from ectopic ACTH secretion. However, the elevated urinary free cortisol and ACTH levels already indicate an ACTH-dependent process. The cosyntropin stimulation test supports adrenal responsiveness, reducing the need for further provocative tests. Imaging studies are preferred for localization after confirming ACTH-dependency.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old healthy woman has her plasma adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), aldosterone, corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and cortisol measured at 8 am (baseline). She then receives 1 mg of dexamethasone at 11 pm, and at 8 am the following morning, the same hormones are re-measured. Which of the following best reflects the expected change in hormone levels on the second day compared to the baseline?



ACTH
Aldosterone
CRH
Cortisol



A
Unchanged
unchanged
increased
increased


B
Increased
increased
unchanged
unchanged


C
Unchanged
increased
decreased
increased


D
Decreased
unchanged
decreased
decreased


E
Increased
decreased
increased
unchanged


F
Decreased
decreased
unchanged
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone levels will remain unchanged, but dexamethasone does not increase CRH or cortisol levels; it suppresses hypothalamic CRH and pituitary ACTH production, thereby lowering endogenous cortisol production.

B) INCORRECT:

Dexamethasone suppresses both CRH and ACTH production, so neither ACTH nor cortisol can remain unchanged or increase. Moreover, an increase in aldosterone levels is not expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Although CRH levels will decrease following dexamethasone administration, ACTH and cortisol levels will also decrease in parallel, and an increase in aldosterone levels is not expected.

D) CORRECT:

Dexamethasone provides supraphysiologic negative feedback to both the hypothalamus and pituitary, sharply reducing CRH production from the hypothalamus and ACTH production from the anterior pituitary. With diminished ACTH production, endogenous glucocorticoid production from the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex also decreases, so plasma cortisol falls by the next morning. In contrast, endogenous mineralocorticoid (aldosterone) secretion is governed chiefly by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and serum potassium, and a transient ACTH suppression produces no appreciable change.

In patients with Cushing syndrome (hypercortisolism), cortisol levels will remain elevated following a low-dose (1 mg) dexamethasone suppression test. Higher doses of dexamethasone can decrease cortisol levels in patients with hypercortisolism due to Cushing disease (ACTH production by a pituitary adenoma).

Key learning point: Negative feedback loops in the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis regulate endogenous glucocorticoid production.

E) INCORRECT:

A glucocorticoid challenge never provokes rises in CRH or ACTH; it uniformly suppresses them and thus lowers cortisol. Moreover, aldosterone would not decrease from this intervention.

F) INCORRECT:

While ACTH and cortisol levels do decrease following dexamethasone administration, CRH levels are expected to decrease similarly due to negative feedback. Moreover, aldosterone would not decrease following a glucocorticoid challenge.
questions.hint: Endogenous glucocorticoid (e.g., cortisol) production is regulated by the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. Dexamethasone is a potent synthetic glucocorticoid, but dexamethasone is not converted to cortisol, and the cortisol assay does not detect dexamethasone itself.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of progressive headache and fatigue. She was diagnosed with Cushing syndrome one year ago and underwent bilateral adrenalectomy. Her current medications are hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone. On examination, she has generalized hyperpigmentation of the skin and bitemporal visual field defects. Serum ACTH concentration is 275 pmol/L (2.2–13.3). Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Up to 10% of patients with small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) develop paraneoplastic syndrome, which may include ectopic production of ACTH (i.e., secondary hypercortisolism). This patient presents with elevated ACTH levels, skin hyperpigmentation, and fatigue, all of which can be seen in secondary hypercortisolism. However, she has no other signs, symptoms, or significant history (e.g., history of cigarette smoking) that suggest a lung malignancy. In addition, progressive headache and bitemporal visual field defects are not consistent with SCLC.

B) CORRECT:

Radiotherapy of the pituitary is a first-line treatment option for patients with Nelson syndrome, a complication that can occur following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing syndrome. Nelson syndrome is thought to result from increased growth of preexisting corticotrophic pituitary microadenomas, which occurs with reduced glucocorticoid feedback inhibition. The hyperpigmentation seen in this patient is due to a combination of excessive melanocyte-stimulating hormone production as a byproduct of ACTH synthesis, and excessively elevated levels of plasma ACTH that stimulate melanocytes to produce melanin. This patient's progressive headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, nausea, and vomiting are due to intracranial mass effect secondary to the growth of corticotrophic pituitary adenomas.

Transsphenoidal surgical excision of the adenoma is the other first-line treatment option for patients with Nelson syndrome.

Key learning point: Nelson syndrome is a complication of bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing syndrome, treated with pituitary radiotherapy or surgical excision due to corticotroph adenoma growth and elevated ACTH.

C) INCORRECT:

Pharmacotherapy with dopamine agonists (e.g., bromocriptine, cabergoline) is the first-line treatment of prolactinomas. Dopamine inhibits pituitary synthesis and release of prolactin, thereby normalizing serum prolactin levels and reducing tumor size. Patients with macroprolactinomas may present with headache and bitemporal hemianopsia, as seen here. However, hyperpigmentation is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, this patient lacks the classic features of hyperprolactinemia, such as gynecomastia, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and menopausal symptoms (e.g., amenorrhea, irregular menses, vaginal atrophy).

D) INCORRECT:

Reduction of glucocorticoid (e.g., hydrocortisone) dosage is indicated in patients with iatrogenic Cushing syndrome due to excessive exogenous glucocorticoid intake. In this condition, high circulating blood levels of (exogenous) glucocorticoids lead to feedback inhibition of pituitary ACTH production. This patient, however, presents with elevated ACTH levels. Moreover, hyperpigmentation of the skin, progressive headache, and bitemporal hemianopsia are inconsistent with iatrogenic hypercortisolism. Furthermore, this patient lacks characteristic features of Cushing syndrome such as central obesity, abnormal fat deposits around the face (“moon facies”), abdominal striae, proximal muscle weakness, and easy bruising.

E) INCORRECT:

Metyrapone inhibits cortisol synthesis in the adrenal cortex and can be used to differentiate primary versus secondary (or tertiary) adrenal insufficiency as part of the metyrapone stimulation test. However, this test requires the presence of an adrenal gland and therefore has no value in this patient who underwent bilateral adrenalectomy.
questions.hint: This patient with Cushing syndrome was treated with a bilateral adrenal resection. She now presents with skin hyperpigmentation, progressive headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, and a massively elevated ACTH level, which is concerning for Nelson syndrome.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of irregular menses and generalized fatigue. Her menses previously occurred at regular 25- to 29-day intervals but now occur every 45 to 60 days. Her body mass index is 37. Blood pressure is 146/100 mm Hg. On examination, she has facial hair and comedones on her face and back. There are multiple ecchymotic patches on her trunk. Neurological examination reveals bilateral weakness of the iliopsoas and biceps muscles. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
131 g/L (115–155)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
13.5 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Sodium (Na), blood
145 mmol/L (136–146)


Potassium (K), blood

3.3 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)


Glucose, random, blood
10.4 mmol/L (4.0–11.0)


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism is one of the most common causes of secondary hypertension. It is caused by elevated circulating aldosterone levels, which result in increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the urine. Although this patient's blood pressure is elevated, her menstrual changes, fatigue, acne, hirsutism, ecchymoses, and proximal muscle weakness are not consistent with hyperaldosteronism.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can present with weight gain, fatigue, menstrual cycle abnormalities, hypertension, muscle weakness, acne, and possibly hirsutism. However, constipation, dry skin, cold intolerance, and delayed relaxation of tendon reflexes would also be expected. Additionally, hypothyroidism would also not explain this patient's ecchymoses, leukocytosis, or hyperglycemia (hypoglycemia is possible instead).

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by high levels of circulating androgens, which leads to virilization, obesity, acne, and hirsutism. Although the clinical presentation of PCOS overlaps with Cushing syndrome, this patient's proximal muscle weakness, ecchymoses, hypertension, and leukocytosis make PCOS less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Cushing syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with menstrual changes, fatigue, acne, hirsutism, ecchymoses, hypertension, and proximal muscle weakness. Irregular menstrual cycles are likely due to the inhibitory effect of high circulating cortisol on gonadotropin release. Hyperglycemia is caused by cortisol stimulating gluconeogenesis, peripheral insulin resistance, and direct suppression of insulin release. Leukocytosis can occur as a result of demargination of neutrophils from vascular walls. Hypokalemia is due to the aldosterone-like effects of cortisol, which stimulates the excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, causing metabolic alkalosis.

Key learning point: Cushing syndrome is characterized by central obesity, hypertension, hirsutism, proximal muscle weakness, ecchymoses, hyperglycemia, leukocytosis, and hypokalemia due to excess cortisol.

E) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal glands, leads to increased sympathetic activity. Patients typically present with episodic hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis. Although this patient has elevated blood pressure, she does not have headaches. Furthermore, symptoms such as menstrual abnormalities, fatigue, acne, and hirsutism are not consistent with pheochromocytoma.
questions.hint: A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test would help confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic because of weight gain over the past 3 months. He has gained 10 kg unintentionally during this period. He also reports decreased sexual desire, oily skin, and difficulty sleeping. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. On examination, he has central obesity, acne, and thin, easily bruisable skin with abdominal striae. There is hyperpigmentation of the mucous membranes and skin creases. Proximal muscle groups show atrophy and weakness. His serum glucose concentration is 13.3 mmol/L (4.0–6.0). Which one of the following findings would most likely be present on imaging?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Endogenous hypercortisolism is most often caused by a pituitary adenoma (approx. 75% of cases), in which case it is referred to as ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, or Cushing disease. This patient presents with the classic features of excess glucocorticoid production, including central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, proximal muscle weakness and atrophy, hypertension, and hyperglycemia. His hyperpigmentation (e.g., darkening of mucous membranes and skin creases) is a unique feature of Cushing disease that results from increased production of ACTH, which is cleaved from the same precursor as melanocyte-stimulating hormone.

Key learning point: Cushing disease is most commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma leading to ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism, often seen as a pituitary mass on imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Adrenal carcinomas can also cause endogenous hypercortisolism, in which case it is referred to as ACTH-independent hypercortisolism. Patients with adrenal carcinoma present similarly to those with benign lesions (either pituitary or adrenal in origin), with central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, and proximal muscle weakness and atrophy. However, adrenal carcinomas are rare in adults and would not be associated with hyperpigmentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can cause secondary hypercortisolism through ectopic ACTH production as a paraneoplastic syndrome. Although RCC is the most common type of kidney tumor in adults, it rarely presents as Cushing syndrome. Moreover, this patient does not have a history of hematuria or any other manifestations (flank pain or mass) consistent with RCC.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased thyroid size can be seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis. Patients with hypothyroidism can present with weight gain, difficulty sleeping, and lethargy. Decreased thyroid hormone can also increase prolactin levels and lead to decreased libido, as seen in this patient, but other features in this patient, particularly the stretch marks, muscle atrophy, hyperpigmentation, and hyperglycemia, are more consistent with Cushing syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer can lead to ectopic ACTH production as a paraneoplastic syndrome, which would also manifest with central obesity, acne, and thin, easily bruisable skin with stretch marks on the abdomen. However, symptoms of lung cancer like cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest pain are missing in this patient, and there are much more common causes of endogenous hypercortisolism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with the typical symptoms of hypercortisolism (e.g., central obesity, thin, easily bruisable skin, stretch marks, and proximal muscle weakness and atrophy). Since he has no history of prolonged glucocorticoid therapy, there must be an endogenous cause.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of worsening fatigue, mood changes, and low libido. Vital signs are BP, 174/98; P, 88; R, 20; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination shows central weight gain, facial rounding, and multiple bruises on her extremities. Laboratory studies show glucose 198 mg/dL, potassium 3.1 mEq/L, and sodium 148 mEq/L. Which additional finding would be most specific for confirming the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proximal muscle weakness is a common finding in Cushing syndrome due to the catabolic effects of cortisol on muscle tissue. However, proximal muscle weakness is not specific and can occur in many neuromuscular and endocrine disorders, including thyroid disease and myopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Hirsutism occurs in Cushing syndrome due to the androgenic effects of excess cortisol. However, it is not specific to hypercortisolism and can occur in polycystic ovary syndrome, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and other androgen excess disorders.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Purple abdominal striae are pathognomonic for Cushing syndrome and represent the most specific physical finding for hypercortisolism. Purple striae result from the catabolic effects of cortisol on collagen, causing skin thinning and the characteristic discoloration that distinguishes them from normal stretch marks.

D) INCORRECT:

Delayed wound healing occurs in Cushing syndrome due to the anti-inflammatory effects of cortisol and impaired collagen synthesis. However, delayed wound healing is not specific and can occur in diabetes, malnutrition, and other conditions that affect tissue repair.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis is a common complication of chronic hypercortisolism due to decreased bone formation and increased bone resorption. However, osteoporosis is not specific to Cushing syndrome and occurs in many metabolic bone diseases and with aging.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents with worsening glycemic control despite medication adherence. She reports a 25-pound weight gain over 8 months, fatigue, and difficulty climbing stairs. Physical examination shows central obesity, facial plethora, and thin skin with easy bruising. BP is 170/100; other vital signs are normal. Her hemoglobin A1c has increased from 7.2% to 9.1% over the past 6 months. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) level is used to differentiate between ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent causes of hypercortisolism. Hypercortisolism has not yet been confirmed in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

CRH stimulation test is used to differentiate between Cushing disease and ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production in patients with confirmed ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism. This specialized test is not used for initial screening of suspected hypercortisolism.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- 24-hour urine free cortisol is one of the three recommended initial screening tests to confirm hypercortisolism, along with low-dose dexamethasone suppression test and late-night salivary cortisol. At least two abnormal results are needed to establish the diagnosis before proceeding with further testing.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used to differentiate between Cushing disease and ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production in patients with confirmed ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism. This test has low accuracy and is not used for initial screening.

E) INCORRECT:

Pituitary MRI evaluates for pituitary adenomas in suspected Cushing disease but is performed after confirming hypercortisolism and determining that it is adrenocorticotropic hormone-dependent.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a 4-month history of central weight gain, purple striae, and increasing weakness presents with altered mental status and fever. She has been treated for hypertension and diabetes over the past 2 months. Physical examination shows a rounded face, dorsocervical fat pad, and poor wound healing from a recent minor injury. Vital signs are BP, 200/115; P, 110; T, 38.9°C (102.0°F). Laboratory studies show glucose 350 mg/dL, K+ 2.6 mEq/L, and WBC 18,000/μL with 85% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Start empirical antibiotics and reassess in 24 hours
Obtain 24-hour urine free cortisol and schedule outpatient endocrinology
Admit for inpatient management and urgent endocrinology consultation
Initiate carbergoline and admit for inpatient management

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While this patient has fever and leukocytosis suggesting possible infection, the constellation of findings strongly suggests Cushing syndrome with serious complications. Increased susceptibility to infections is a known complication of hypercortisolism, but the priority is comprehensive inpatient management rather than isolated antibiotic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose dexamethasone suppression testing is used to differentiate between Cushing disease and ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production in patients with confirmed ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism. This specialized test is not appropriate for initial diagnosis confirmation and does not address the immediate management needs.

C) INCORRECT:

Although 24-hour urine free cortisol is appropriate for initial testing to confirm hypercortisolism, this patient has complications requiring immediate inpatient management, including altered mental status, severe hypertension, hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has clinical features consistent with Cushing syndrome complicated by altered mental status, hypertensive crisis, severe hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia. Patients with suspected hypercortisolism should be referred to endocrinology, and the severity of complications in this patient, including neurological changes and metabolic derangements, necessitates immediate inpatient management with urgent specialist consultation.

E) INCORRECT:

While carbergoline is a second-line treatment for Cushing syndrome, this patient's diagnosis has not been confirmed, and pharmacological decisions should be guided by an endocrinologist.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of progressive central weight gain, fatigue, and facial rounding. She was recently diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Physical examination reveals facial plethora, a dorsocervical fat pad, and wide, purplish striae on her abdomen. Initial laboratory workup shows a high morning cortisol level that fails to suppress with a low-dose dexamethasone test. Subsequent testing reveals a suppressed plasma ACTH level of <5 pg/mL. An abdominal CT scan identifies a 3-cm, well-circumscribed, right-sided adrenal mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Unilateral adrenalectomy is the definitive, curative treatment for a solitary functional adrenal adenoma. Surgical removal of the tumor normalizes cortisol levels and resolves the associated signs, symptoms, and comorbidities. Following surgery, patients often require temporary glucocorticoid replacement because the chronic excess cortisol from the tumor suppresses the entire hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, leading to atrophy of the contralateral adrenal gland.

B) INCORRECT:

Pasireotide is a somatostatin analog that reduces ACTH secretion from pituitary adenomas. It is a medical therapy for Cushing's disease (ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome). This medication would be ineffective in this patient, whose condition is ACTH-independent.

C) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal surgery is the first-line treatment for Cushing's disease, which is caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. However, this patient's ACTH level is suppressed, not elevated, which effectively rules out a pituitary source for her hypercortisolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Bilateral adrenalectomy is a treatment option for refractory Cushing's disease or certain forms of bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. It is not indicated here, as imaging clearly demonstrates a unilateral adrenal mass responsible for the hypercortisolism. Removing both glands would be unnecessarily aggressive and would require lifelong glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement.

E) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole inhibits steroidogenesis and can be used to medically manage hypercortisolism. However, it is typically reserved for patients who are poor surgical candidates or as a bridging therapy to definitive surgery. For a patient with a resectable unilateral adrenal adenoma, surgery is the preferred curative treatment, not long-term medical management.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation, nonsuppressible cortisol, and suppressed ACTH level establish a diagnosis of ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. The abdominal CT confirms the source is a unilateral adrenal mass, most likely a cortisol-producing adenoma.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents for a follow-up visit. She reports a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight gain over the past year, easy bruising, and feeling "puffy." She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Her medications include methotrexate and prednisone, which she has been taking for two years. Her blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg, an increase from 125/80 mm Hg at her last visit. Physical examination shows central obesity, facial plethora, a dorsocervical fat pad, and wide, purplish striae on her abdomen. A random blood glucose is 180 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?

choices.text: Initiate a gradual taper of the prednisone dose
Order a 24-hour urinary free cortisol measurement
Add a biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drug

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most appropriate management for iatrogenic Cushing syndrome from long-term glucocorticoid (e.g., prednisone) use is to gradually taper the glucocorticoid dose. Chronic exogenous steroid use suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, leading to adrenal atrophy. A slow taper allows the HPA axis to recover and resume endogenous cortisol production. This minimizes the risk of precipitating a life-threatening adrenal crisis, characterized by hypotension, shock, and hypoglycemia, which would occur with abrupt cessation. The taper should be done while ensuring the underlying rheumatoid arthritis remains controlled.

B) INCORRECT:

A 24-hour urinary free cortisol measurement is a diagnostic test for endogenous Cushing syndrome, in which the body produces excess cortisol. This patient's cushingoid features are caused by exogenous prednisone administration. Therefore, diagnostic testing for an endogenous source is unnecessary and does not address the immediate management of this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Although reducing this patient's exposure to prednisone is necessary, immediate discontinuation is dangerous. Long-term use of exogenous glucocorticoids suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, causing adrenal atrophy. Abruptly stopping the medication would likely precipitate an acute adrenal crisis, which is a medical emergency.

D) INCORRECT:

An adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulation test is used to diagnose adrenal insufficiency. Although this patient is presumed to have secondary adrenal insufficiency due to hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression from chronic steroid use, this test is not needed to make that determination. The immediate management step is to address the hypercortisolism by tapering the prednisone, not to confirm the expected adrenal suppression.

E) INCORRECT:

Adding a biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drug may be part of the long-term strategy to control this patient's rheumatoid arthritis and facilitate steroid reduction. However, it is not the most appropriate next step. The immediate priority is to address the significant metabolic and cardiovascular complications of iatrogenic Cushing syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation of central obesity, facial plethora, a dorsocervical fat pad, purple striae, hypertension, and hyperglycemia is suggestive of iatrogenic Cushing syndrome.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office due to a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and weight gain, primarily around her midsection. She also reports easy bruising. Her medical history is significant for newly diagnosed hypertension. On examination, she has central adiposity, a round face, and thin skin. Her blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Enlargement of the hands and feet
Delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes
Wide, purplish striae on the abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acral enlargement, or the enlargement of hands and feet, is a characteristic feature of acromegaly, which results from excess growth hormone. While acromegaly can cause hypertension and fatigue, it does not typically cause the central obesity, moon facies, or thin, easily bruised skin seen in this patient. Instead, it manifests with coarsening of facial features and prognathism.

B) INCORRECT:

Delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, or Woltman sign, is a classic finding in hypothyroidism. While hypothyroidism can manifest with fatigue and weight gain, this patient's other features, such as central adiposity, thin skin, easy bruising, and new-onset hypertension, are not characteristic of this condition. The weight gain in hypothyroidism is typically more generalized and related to fluid retention and decreased metabolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Exophthalmos, or protrusion of the eyeballs, is a specific sign of Graves disease, an autoimmune cause of hyperthyroidism. Although hyperthyroidism can cause fatigue and hypertension, it classically causes weight loss despite an increased appetite. This patient's presentation of central weight gain, moon facies, and thin skin is inconsistent with a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism.

D) CORRECT:

Hypercortisolism has catabolic effects on peripheral tissues, including inhibiting fibroblast proliferation and collagen synthesis in the skin. This leads to dermal thinning and loss of connective tissue integrity. As central fat accumulates and stretches the weakened skin, the underlying blood vessels become visible, resulting in wide, purplish, or violaceous striae. These are most commonly found on the abdomen but also on the breasts, hips, and axillae. This finding is highly specific for Cushing syndrome, distinguishing it from the striae seen in pregnancy or simple obesity, which are typically pink or flesh-colored and narrower.
questions.hint: This patient's constellation of central obesity, moon facies, easy bruising, and hypertension suggests a diagnosis of Cushing syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of progressive weight gain and increasing fatigue. She notes that the weight gain is primarily in her abdomen and face, whereas her arms and legs seem thinner. She also reports irregular menstrual cycles and easy bruising. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Her blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, a rounded plethoric face, and several 1.5-cm-wide, purplish striae on her lower abdomen. There is mild weakness with hip flexion against resistance. A random glucose level is 145 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome can manifest with obesity and irregular menstrual cycles. However, it is primarily a disorder of hyperandrogenism and anovulation. It does not typically cause the prominent catabolic features seen in this patient, such as proximal muscle weakness, easy bruising, or the characteristic wide, purplish striae. Although striae can occur with weight gain, they are usually not violaceous.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause weight gain, fatigue, and menstrual irregularities. However, the weight gain is typically generalized and often involves fluid retention, not the specific centripetal pattern with thinning extremities seen in this patient. Furthermore, hypothyroidism does not explain the hypertension, hyperglycemia, proximal muscle weakness, or wide, purplish striae.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for Cushing syndrome, a condition caused by chronic exposure to excess cortisol. The key features are due to the catabolic and metabolic effects of glucocorticoids. Centripetal obesity, a rounded plethoric face (moon facies), and supraclavicular fat pads result from fat redistribution. The catabolic effects on protein cause proximal muscle weakness, skin thinning that leads to easy bruising, and breakdown of subcutaneous collagen that results in wide (>1 cm), violaceous striae. Other common findings present in this patient include hypertension, menstrual irregularities, and hyperglycemia. The diagnosis is confirmed by tests such as a 24-hour urinary free cortisol, late-night salivary cortisol, or a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient meets several criteria for metabolic syndrome, including central obesity, hypertension, and elevated glucose. However, metabolic syndrome is a constellation of risk factors rather than a single underlying diagnosis that explains the entire clinical picture. It does not account for the specific findings of proximal muscle weakness, easy bruising, wide purplish striae, or menstrual irregularities.
questions.hint: Centripetal obesity, proximal muscle weakness, and wide, purplish striae are highly specific findings for a single underlying endocrine disorder caused by excess glucocorticoids.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of progressive facial rounding, easy bruising, and unintentional weight gain. She also notes darkening of her skin, particularly over her knuckles and palmar creases. Examination shows purple striae across her abdomen and mild proximal muscle weakness (see lab results).

Blood pressure
158/90 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Cortisol 8 a.m.
700 nmol/L
138 - 635 nmol/L


ACTH
15 pmol/L
2 - 11 pmol/L



Which of the following is the most likely cause of her presentation?

choices.text: Ectopic ACTH production by a bronchial carcinoid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exogenous glucocorticoid use leads to Cushing syndrome with features like weight gain and moon facies. However, it suppresses ACTH due to negative feedback, resulting in low endogenous cortisol. The elevated ACTH and cortisol levels, along with hyperpigmentation, are inconsistent with exogenous glucocorticoid use.

B) CORRECT:

An adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-secreting pituitary adenoma causes Cushing disease, characterized by excessive ACTH production, leading to bilateral adrenal hyperplasia and increased cortisol secretion. Clinical features include moon facies, easy bruising, weight gain, purple striae, proximal muscle weakness, and hypertension. Hyperpigmentation over the knuckles results from elevated ACTH, which shares a precursor with melanocyte-stimulating hormone, increasing melanin synthesis. The elevated cortisol and ACTH levels in this young woman suggest an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

Key learning point: Cushing disease is characterized by symptoms of Cushing syndrome with elevated ACTH levels, often leading to hyperpigmentation, and is caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Ectopic ACTH production causes ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome, often with rapid progression and very high ACTH levels. This patient has modestly elevated ACTH and lacks respiratory symptoms or imaging abnormalities typical of bronchial carcinoids. The age and symptom development suggest a pituitary source.

D) INCORRECT:

A cortisol-producing adrenal adenoma causes autonomous cortisol secretion, leading to suppressed ACTH levels. The elevated ACTH in this patient indicates an ACTH-dependent process. Hyperpigmentation from elevated ACTH further argues against an adrenal adenoma.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of fatigue, irregular menstrual cycles, and recurrent sinus infections. Examination shows hirsutism and hypopigmented linear striations on the abdomen. Serum studies show hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Midnight salivary cortisol concentration and 24-hour urinary cortisol concentration are increased. Serum ACTH is also elevated. High-dose dexamethasone does not suppress serum cortisol levels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excess cortisol production by an adrenal carcinoma would suppress pituitary secretion of ACTH, leading to low ACTH levels and ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Excess cortisol production by an adrenal adenoma would suppress pituitary secretion of ACTH, leading to low ACTH levels and ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Exogenous corticosteroid administration causes negative feedback on ACTH production in the pituitary gland, causing low ACTH levels and presenting as ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome. This patient has elevated ACTH levels (ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome).

Exogenous corticosteroid administration should be considered in patients who work in healthcare settings and have access to medications (physicians, nurses, medical assistants, etc.).

D) INCORRECT:

A corticotropic pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) would result in secondary hypercortisolism due to increased ACTH production by the tumor. However, ACTH production by corticotropic pituitary adenomas is responsive to suppressive feedback by high-doses of dexamethasone, and cortisol levels would be expected to decrease. The elevated cortisol levels in this patient following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test suggest a different cause of secondary hypercortisolism.

E) INCORRECT:

In very rare cases, pheochromocytomas may present with ectopic ACTH production. However, this patient does not have any of the classic symptoms of pheochromocytoma, e.g., paroxysmal elevations in heart rate and blood pressure with palpitations or diaphoresis.

F) CORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing syndrome from an ectopic ACTH source. A history of smoking is the biggest risk factor for SCLC. As a neuroendocrine tumor, SCLC can produce hormones that are associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, including Cushing syndrome, SIADH, and Lambert-Eaton syndrome. Neoplastic small cells produce ACTH, which is not suppressed by high cortisol and is resistant to negative feedback, which causes serum cortisol to remain elevated following the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test.

Other cancers that are less commonly associated with the secretion of ACTH or ACTH-like substances include renal cell cancer, bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors, and medullary thyroid carcinomas.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms, examination findings, and electrolyte abnormalities are consistent with hypercortisolism (Cushing syndrome); the diagnosis is confirmed by the findings of elevated urinary and late-night salivary cortisol. The finding of elevated ACTH is consistent with secondary hypercortisolism. The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test differentiates between excess ACTH production of pituitary and nonpituitary (ectopic) origin.
